_prev_prog_3.Description: The following information applies to the Fresh Express Grand Prairie Facility ammonia refrigeration process, which is the only process covered under this RMP [Note: The letter prefacing each item below corresponds to the subsection of 40 CFR 68.175 requiring that information. As a result, subsection (a) is intentionally excluded.]

_exec_summary.SummaryText:
1.    Executive Summary



Accidental Release Prevention and Emergency Response Policies

The management of Fresh Express is committed to maintaining a safe work environment.  A Safety and Security Manager has been assigned to ensure that safe practices are followed in the specification and operation of systems involving hazardous chemicals.  This site has developed and trained a Quick Response Team to ensure rapid and appropriate response to ammonia emergencies.  The site has specific and written evacuation, reporting, and response procedures in place to protect Fresh Express employees, the public, and the environment in the event of an ammonia release. 



Stationary Source and Regulated Substance

The Fresh Express plant covered by this RMP is located at 2370 W. Warrior Trail, Grand Prairie, Texas. The facility receives lettuce and other produce to be processed, packaged for consumer use in various salad mixes, set for short-term storage, and transported and distributed from this site.



The regulated substance is anhydrous ammonia.  One closed loop ammonia refrigeration system is used for refrigerating produce at various temperatures. The total charge to this refrigeration system is 15,000 pounds of anhydrous ammonia.  



Release Scenarios

The Worst Case and Alternate Case release scenarios were determined using ALOHA and Marplot.  ALOHA warns that ammonia "may flash boil or result in two phase flow" and therefore both the Gaussian and Heavy Gas model were evaluated.  Both dispersion models were utilized.  The one providing the greatest distance, leading to the greatest impact was selected for use. 



The worst-case release scenario considered for this process is a release of the volume of the single Low Temperature Receiver (V-01) (a maximum of (11834.4 lbs.).  No administrative controls and mitigation measures were considered to limit the off-site consequence distance for this scenario.  The estimated distance to the toxic endpoint for the worst-case scena

rio is 0.894 miles.



The alternative release scenario considered for this process is a release of ammonia through the largest pressure relief device caused by a failure of that valve.  The calculated adjusted valve capacity is 86.2 Lbs per minute.  It was assumed operator intervention would divert the flow from the failed relief valve using the three way manifold within 15 minutes,  so a release of 1293 Lbs over 15 minutes was used.  No administrative controls or mitigation measures were considered to limit the off-site consequence distance for this scenario.  The estimated distance to the toxic endpoint for the alternative release scenario is 0.23 miles.



Accidental Release Prevention Program and Chemical-Specific Prevention Steps

Prevention of accidental ammonia release at Fresh Express is accomplished through sound industry practice in the original ammonia refrigeration system design and construction, the specification and review of system modifications, and the day-to-day operation and maintenance of the system.  



This includes:

?    Compliance with industry standards and codes in effect at the time of initial construction and modification

?    Performance of a thorough Process Hazard Analyses (PHAs) at least once every five years using accurate Process Safety Information

?    Implementation of Operating Procedures which have been reviewed by PHA

?    Appropriate initial and refresher training of system operations and maintenance personnel  

?    Performance of preventive and corrective maintenance according to system component manufacturer recommendations and pursuant to site wide hazardous energy lockout and hot work permit programs

?    Application of established auditing, inspection, and pre-start-up review protocols

?    Use of qualified contractors for work on the system

The detailed Ammonia System Release Prevention Program is contained in a supporting document (revised and updated July, 2010) that is maintained by the site's Safety and Security Manager.



Fi

d outdoors.  

The site is located 17 miles southwest of Dallas, Texas near the intersection of Arkansas Lane and South Great Southwest Parkway, in Grand Prairie.  The facility is surrounded by residential and commercial areas.  Grand Prairie Municipal Airport lies to the west of the Fresh Express property.  

Because the ammonia refrigeration system is considered a Program 3 process, one worst-case release scenario and an alternative release scenario have been analyzed for this RMP. 

OCA Methodology

The analyses herein follow the requirements specified by the Federal RMP (40 CFR 68.22). The method utilizes ALOHA and MARPLOT to develop the distance to the Toxic End Point and plot that distance on a map.  This impact zone is used to evaluate the various impacts of the modeled release.

Release Scenarios

Worst-Case Release Scenario Analysis

Since the Fresh Express ammonia refrigeration system is considered an RMP Program 3 process, the worst-case release scenario was identified as that which was estimated to create the greatest distance in any direction to the toxic endpoint for ammonia.  The worst-case release quantity was defined as the greatest amount potentially held in a single vessel location (i.e., 11,834.4 pounds in the Low Temperature Receiver (V-01)). No mitigating controls were assumed.

Pursuant to the Environmental Protection Agency 68.22, the meteorological and site specific variables assumed for the analysis are as follows:

Worst-Case Release Scenario Assumptions

 Chemical Name:

 Anhydrous Ammonia

 Physical State:

 Pressurized Liquid

 Basis of Results:

 ALOHA 5.4.5/ MARPLOT 5.0.1

 Scenario:

 Liquid spill vaporizes to airborne vapor and droplets

 Quantity Released, lbs:

11,834.4

Release Rate:

 1,385 lbs/min (see text, this Section)

 Release Duration:

 10 minutes

 Wind Speed:

 10 MPH

 Atmospheric Stability Class:

D

 Topography (Surface Roughness)

 Urban

Toxic Endpoint Concentration:

 200 PPM

 Distance to Endpoint, mi:

 0.894 m

i 

 Vessel or System Considered:

 Single Low Temperature Recirculator

 Vessel Location:

 Indoors

 Passive Mitigation Considered:

 None

Release Rate - Ammonia is a liquid under pressure in this part of the refrigeration system.  The guidance specifies the release rate as the quantity released as a gas over 10 minutes.  This rapid release of ammonia is an airborne mixture of vapor and droplets.   The release rate is calculated as follows:

QR = Q/10

Where:       QR = Release Rate (lbs/min)

                 Q = Quantity Released (lbs)

Using our scenario criteria:

QR = 11,834.4 lbs / 10 min  = 1,183.4 lbs/min (unmitigated)

Distance to the Toxic Endpoint - Based on the estimated worst-case release rate of 1,183.4 lbs/min, ALOHA shows the distance to the toxic endpoint at 0.894 miles from the Low Temperature Receiver (V-01).  The "urban" distance was used, since there are buildings in the immediate area.

Receptors:

Residential Populations

The Marplot mapping program was used to pinpoint the Fresh Express facility and estimate populations within the release scenario radius.  Using the population estimator within the Marplot program both the Gaussian Model and Heavy Gas Model were evaluated.  It was determined the larger population would result from the heavy Gas Model.  According to this model using the 2010 census data, 2,262 housing units representing 6,780 people are located within the 0.894-mile radius of the worst-case release scenario.  

 MARPLOT  maps depicting the worst-case and alternative release vapor cloud radii are included.

Other Public Receptors

In addition to residences, public receptors that must be noted in the RMP are schools, hospitals, long-term health care and child day care facilities, prisons, public recreational areas, and major commercial or industrial areas.  There are three (3) churches, two (2) heliports, one (1) school, one (1) airport.  Within the alternative release scenario radius, there is one (1) school and one (1) churc

h.

Environmental Receptors

Environmental receptors that must be noted in the RMP are natural areas, such as national or state parks, forests or monuments; wildlife sanctuaries, preserves, refuges or areas; and Federal wilderness areas.  None of these types of receptors appear to be located within the worst-case or alternative release scenario circles.

Alternative Release Scenario Analysis

Pursuant to RMP regulations, the alternative release scenario was identified as that which is more likely to occur than the worst-case release scenario, and that which will reach an endpoint offsite.  Since actual atmospheric data was used for the Worst Case analysis, the alternative release scenario used the same atmospheric data used for the worst case.  

In review of the previous alternate case release it was decided to re-evaluate the previous scenario using current data for the relief valve with the greatest rated release volume. This turned out to be a Shank 805 (250PSIG) relief valve located on vessel V-1.  Previous calculations indicate an adjusted valve capacity of 86.2 lb/min.  Facility personnel are comfortable that should this valve fail personnel would be able to respond and divert the three way valve to the alternate relief valve within 15 minutes, therefore a fifteen minute release was used for this evaluation.

The scenario chosen is a lifted pressure relief device that has lifted due to a failure of the relief valve.  A release rate of 86.2 Lbs /Min for 15 minutes would result in a total release of 1293 Lbs of ammonia.

The alternative release scenario variables and assumptions are therefore as follows:

Alternative Release Scenario Assumptions

 Chemical Name:

 Anhydrous Ammonia

 Physical State:

 Pressurized vapor

 Basis of Results:

 ALOHA 5.4.5/ MARPLOT 5.0.1

 Scenario:

 Release of ammonia through a failed pressure relief device

Quantity Released, lbs:

 1293 lbs 

 Release Rate:

86.2 lbs/min  

Release Duration:

 15 minutes

 Wind Speed:

 10 MPH

Atmospheric Stability Class:

 D

 Topography (Surface Roughness):

 Urban

 Toxic Endpoint Concentration:

 200 PPM

Distance to Endpoint, mi:

397 Yards

 Receptors:

System Considered:

 Low Temperature Receiver (V-01)

 Passive Mitigation Considered:

 None

 Active Mitigation Considered:

 None

 Distance to the Toxic Endpoint - Based on the estimated alternative scenario release rate of 86.2 lbs/min, ALOHA / MARPLOT shows the distance to the toxic endpoint at 397 Yards.

Total population within distance to endpoint:

The same Heavy Gas modeling technique and population estimator previously used in the worst case scenario was used to determine that there are 183 housing units representing  579 people  residing within the  397 yard radius of the alternative release scenario.
